headline.main: Laugh Lines

results.snippet: JAY LENO     Scary incident yesterday for the Chief Justice of the Supreme CourtJohn Roberts -- luckily, he's O.K. Yesterday he collapsed to the ground outside his vacation home in Maine. Turns out he had a seizure. At first people thought he had...
results.lead_paragraph: JAY LENO Scary incident yesterday for the Chief Justice of the Supreme CourtJohn Roberts -- luckily, he's O.K. Yesterday he collapsed to the ground outside his vacation home in Maine. Turns out he had a seizure. At first people thought he had just fallen over from leaning too far to the right. For you young people, John Roberts is our most important judge, after Simon Cowell.

results.abstract: Scott Kelly, commander of the next space shuttle mission, sent a letter to a number of newspapers, taking issue with the reports that some astronauts had been drinking alcohol and perhaps were even intoxicated just before flight. The letter was released by NASA. It was with much regret that I read some of the reporting [...]

headline.main: Space Shuttle Commander Disputes Alcohol Reports

results.snippet: Scott Kelly, commander of the next space shuttle mission, sent a letter to a number of newspapers, taking issue with the reports that some astronauts had been drinking alcohol and perhaps were even intoxicated just before flight. The letter was...
results.lead_paragraph: Scott Kelly, commander of the next space shuttle mission, sent a letter to a number of newspapers, taking issue with the reports that some astronauts had been drinking alcohol and perhaps were even intoxicated just before flight. The letter was released by NASA.

headline.main: Astronaut Profiles

results.snippet: Profiles of the seven members of STS-118, which will bring structural elements up to the International Space Station and carry on the process of building the station.
results.lead_paragraph: The seven members of the crew of the current mission of the space shuttle Endeavour include a teacher-astronaut, an electrician-turned-chemist, combat pilots and a doctor. The mission, which is officially designated as STS-118, will bring new structural elements up to the International Space Station and carry on the process of building the station. The crew:

results.abstract: Barbara R Morgan is about to fulfill two-decade-old dream by becoming first 'educator astronaut' when she and six fellow astronauts blast off in space shuttle Endeavour on Aug 8 on mission to International Space Station; she was backup to first teacher in space, Christa McAuliffe, who died in Challenger explosion in 1986; photo (M)

headline.main: Teacher-Astronaut to Fly Decades After Challenger

results.snippet: Barbara R. Morgan, a former teacher, is about to fulfill a two-decade-old dream by becoming the first “educator astronaut.”
results.lead_paragraph: Barbara R. Morgan is now an astronaut by profession, heading into space this week for the first time on the space shuttle. But she said she would be approaching her mission ''with the mind, eyes, ears and heart of a teacher.'' ''That's what I am, a teacher,'' Ms. Morgan said, ''That's what I am at my core.''

results.abstract: Cmdr Scott J Kelly, commander of space shuttle mission scheduled to be launched Aug 8, sends letter to several newspapers saying recent reports of alcohol use by astronauts had been exaggerated in news accounts (S)

headline.main: News Reports Are Criticized By Astronaut

results.snippet: The commander of the space shuttle mission scheduled to be launched on Tuesday sent a letter saying that reports of alcohol use by astronauts had been exaggerated.
results.lead_paragraph: Cmdr. Scott J. Kelly, commander of the space shuttle mission scheduled to be launched tomorrow, has sent a letter to several newspapers saying recent reports of alcohol use by astronauts had been exaggerated in news accounts. In the letter, released yesterday by NASA, Commander Kelly, of the Navy, wrote, ''To imply that my crew or I would ever consider launching on our mission in anything but the best possible condition is utterly ridiculous.''

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off and head to International Space Station (S)

headline.main: NATIONAL BRIEFING | SCIENCE AND HEALTH | Space Shuttle Set To Lift Off

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off this evening and head to the International Space Station. The 10-minute launching window starts at 6:31 p.m. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather,...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off this evening and head to the International Space Station. The 10-minute launching window starts at 6:31 p.m. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, with a small chance of showers the only concern. The Endeavour is carrying a truss segment to be added to the space station in the first of four spacewalks. The mission is scheduled to last 11 days, but will be extended to 14 days if a new system allowing the shuttle to draw electrical power from the station works as planned. NASA will broadcast the launching live at www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/.

results.abstract: FC Dallas goalie Ray Burse Jr records first Major League Soccer shutout against Colorado Rapids; photo (M)

headline.main: Goalie Puts Education First And Career Second

results.snippet: It is only fitting that Ray Burse Jr. was focused on education, taking a summer-school class on the history of Reconstruction and the Civil War, when he received a voice-mail message from F.C. Dallas Coach Steve Morrow telling him he should prepare...
results.lead_paragraph: It is only fitting that Ray Burse Jr. was focused on education, taking a summer-school class on the history of Reconstruction and the Civil War, when he received a voice-mail message from F.C. Dallas Coach Steve Morrow telling him he should prepare for the first start of his professional soccer career. ''I left the lecture to check my messages, went back into class, but left early,'' Burse said.

headline.main: Goalie Puts Education First And Career Second

results.snippet: F.C. Dallas’s Ray Burse Jr. will graduate from Ohio State later this month with a degree in American history after shuttling between Dallas and Columbus one day a week this past semester.
results.lead_paragraph: It is only fitting that Ray Burse Jr. was focused on education, taking a summer-school class on the history of Reconstruction and the Civil War, when he received a voice-mail message from F.C. Dallas Coach Steve Morrow telling him he should prepare for the first start of his professional soccer career. ''I left the lecture to check my messages, went back into class, but left early,'' Burse said.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour leaves on 11-day mission to International Space Station; Endeavour astronaut Barbara R Morgan was backup to first teacher in space Christa McAuliffe who died in 1986 Challenger explosion; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Endeavour, With Challenger Legacy, Takes Off

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into humid skies on Wednesday evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago. One of the Endeavour's astronauts, Barbara R. Morgan, was the backup to Christa McAuliffe for the teacher-in-space program in 1986. Ms. Morgan was one of the spectators at the Kennedy Space Center when the Challenger exploded 73 seconds into flight on Jan. 28, 1986, killing Ms. McAuliffe and the other six astronauts.

headline.main: Endeavour Ready for Evening Launch

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour is fueled up and ready for liftoff at 6:36 p.m. today. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, and launching preparations have proceeded without any glitches.     NASA will broadcast the launching live at...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour is fueled up and ready for liftoff at 6:36 p.m. today. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, and launching preparations have proceeded without any glitches. NASA will broadcast the launching live at www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/.

results.abstract: Capt Lisa M Nowak, former astronaut charged with attempted kidnapping of romantic rival Capt Colleen Shipman, says in court filing electronic monitor she wears interferes with her work and family life; device is condition of her release from jail; photo (M)

headline.main: Former Astronaut Seeking To Be Free of Ankle Monitor

results.snippet: Capt. Lisa Nowak says that the electronic monitoring device she is wearing as a condition of her release from jail is a personal, physical and financial hardship.
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak wants to get rid of her ankle bracelet. A lawyer for Captain Nowak, the former astronaut charged with attempted kidnapping in February after driving from Texas to Florida to confront a romantic rival, argued in papers filed in Florida Circuit Court in Orlando yesterday that the electronic monitoring device was a personal, physical and financial hardship. She has been wearing the device as a condition of her release from jail.

results.abstract: NASA officials say small but deep gouge in underside of space shuttle Endeavour, caused by debris hitting craft during liftoff, does not pose potential catastrophe and may not be fixed in space; photos; diagram (M)

headline.main: Gouged Tile May Be Left Unrepaired, NASA Says

results.snippet: Damage in the shuttle would not be catastrophic upon re-entry into the atmosphere, according to the space agency.
results.lead_paragraph: A small but deep gouge in the underside of the space shuttle Endeavour does not pose the potential of catastrophe, the NASA official overseeing the mission said yesterday. ''I don't even know if I have to go to fix this at all,'' said John Shannon, chairman of the mission management team at a news conference. ''This is not a catastrophic loss-of-orbiter case at all.''

results.abstract: Barbara R Morgan teaches students at Discovery Center of Idaho in Boise from aboard International Space Station; Morgan was backup to Christa McAuliffe, who died in Challenger explosion in 1986, the last time NASA tried to send teacher into space; photo (M)

headline.main: Astronaut Teaches in Space, and Lesson Is Bittersweet

results.snippet: Barbara R. Morgan’s lesson from space was just over 20 minutes, but it was supposed to make up for more than 20 years.
results.lead_paragraph: Barbara R. Morgan got back to teaching yesterday. The students were in Idaho; she was in space, orbiting aboard the International Space Station. The lesson was just over 20 minutes, but it was supposed to make up for more than 20 years, and it had a bittersweet air for those who knew the history. The last time NASA tried to send a teacher into space, Christa McAuliffe in 1986, the shuttle Challenger broke up 73 seconds into the flight, killing all seven crew members. Ms. Morgan, a teacher from Idaho who was Ms. McAuliffe's backup, was at Kennedy Space Center, watching.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Endeavour will study plans for conducting repair of small gash on underside of shuttle; mission managers have not made decision to carry out repair; say results so far indicate that no repair is necessary and that Endeavour could fly home as is; during liftoff piece of foam fell from external fuel tank and hit underside of orbiter; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Crew Is Told to Study For Repairs, as NASA Wavers

results.snippet: Astronauts aboard the Endeavour will spend Thursday studying plans for conducting the first in-flight repair of the shuttle’s thermal tiles.
results.lead_paragraph: In a change of plans, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour will spend today studying plans for conducting a repair of the shuttle. Mission managers have not made a decision to carry out the repair, to patch a small gash on the underside of the Endeavour, and they said experimental and computational results so far indicated that no repair was necessary and that the Endeavour could fly home as is.

results.abstract: Op-Ed article by MIT Prof Alan Lightman describes sailing into New York Harbor with his brother aboard 49-foot Taswell sloop from Annapolis, Md (M)

headline.main: Sailboat With a View

results.snippet: A perspective that brings New York City down to size.
results.section_name: Travel; New York and Region; Opinion
results.lead_paragraph: EARLIER this summer, on a quiet Sunday, I glided into New York Harbor by sailboat. I had been sailing with my brother on the Promise, his 49-foot Taswell sloop. We left Annapolis, Md., two days earlier, sailed up the Chesapeake Bay, motored east through the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, turned south into the Delaware Bay, rounded Cape May, N.J., and then headed north again in the open Atlantic until we reached the Lower New York Bay. At times, we had been beyond sight of land, surrounded by nothing but ocean, from horizon to horizon.

results.abstract: The Gift column discusses bull rider Adriano Moraes; photo (M)

headline.main: THE GIFT

results.snippet: Bull rider Adriano Moraes and the art of animalmanagement.
results.lead_paragraph: A successful bull ride is eight seconds of waltz crossed with a wrestling match. The cowboy tries to situate his center of gravity over the bull's and somehow convince the judges that he, not the 1,500-pound bull, is dancing lead. In the 14-year history of the Professional Bull Riders tour, no one has done a better job of that than Adriano Moraes, who first rode a calf as a child in Brazil. Moraes, 37, is the oldest and most decorated member of the circuit, winner of an unprecedented three world championships, in 1994, 2001 and 2006. How has the old man -- on perhaps his last lap around the circuit -- managed to succeed, let alone survive, in this young man's sport? SITTING PRETTY

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavor lands safely despite damage to two heat tiles on underside of right wing caused by falling foam, concluding successful mission; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Glides Safely Home in Spite of 2 Gouged Tiles

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing at the Kennedy Space Center, apparently not much worse for wear.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing here Tuesday afternoon, apparently not much worse for wear. A look at the underside of the Endeavour appeared to validate the decision by mission managers not to try to repair a small but deep gouge, caused by a falling piece of foam, in two heat tiles on the underside of the right wing. The ultrahot gases streaming past the wing surface on re-entry burned a slightly larger scoop out of the gouged tiles, but the additional damage to the craft appeared to be limited.

headline.main: The Space Shuttle Hobbles Onward

results.snippet: It has become clear that the shuttle’s design, which puts a large fuel tank insulated with foam above a fragile spacecraft, is fundamentally flawed.
results.lead_paragraph: What started two weeks ago as a routine space shuttle flight to service the international space station and let a teacher-astronaut inspire students from her perch in space turned into a bit of a nail-biter when the shuttle Endeavor suffered minor damage during liftoff. In the end, NASA handled the problem deftly, and the shuttle landed safely at the Kennedy Space Center yesterday. But it was a troubling reminder that the aging shuttles have some inherent defects that will always pose a risk as they limp toward retirement in 2010. Under the shattering forces of liftoff, a small piece of foam, weighing about one-third of an ounce, fell from the Endeavor's external fuel tank, bounced off a strut and hit the underside of the orbiter, where it gouged a small hole in the protective heat tiles. The hole was deep enough in one area to penetrate the entire thickness of the tiles. This was worrisome because the shuttle Columbia was destroyed in 2003 when a much bigger piece of foam fell off and gouged a hole in its wing, allowing hot gases to penetrate the vehicle during re-entry.

results.abstract: Lisa Nowak's lawyers want the judge to suppress her statements to police and everything they found in her car. And they want to get rid of the ankle bracelet.

headline.main: In Court Today: The Astronaut Soap Opera

results.snippet: Lisa Nowak's lawyers want the judge to suppress her statements to police and everything they found in her car. And they want to get rid of the ankle bracelet.
results.lead_paragraph: Update 3:45 p.m. EasternJohn Schwartz called The Lede from the courthouse with an update: After the lunch break, the proceedings were taken up mainly by the defense's efforts to persuade the judge that the police acted without Captain Nowak's consent in searching her car and in taking her statement without her lawyer present -- familiar battlegrounds in many criminal cases (not to mention television shows).

results.abstract: Capt Lisa M Nowak, Navy officer and former astronaut, testifies at pretrial hearing involving charges that she had tried to kidnap Capt Colleen Shipman, romantic rival, after marathon drive from Texas to Florida; photos show Nowak and Shipman in Orlando, Fla, courthouse (M)

headline.main: Women in NASA Triangle Face Each Other in Court

results.snippet: Seven months after Capt. Lisa Nowak’s alleged attempt to kidnap Capt. Colleen Shipman, a romantic rival, the two women met again in a tense courtroom.
results.lead_paragraph: The first time Capt. Lisa M. Nowak met Capt. Colleen Shipman was seven months ago in a parking lot at Orlando International Airport. They were together again on Friday, in a tense courtroom. Captain Nowak, a Navy officer and a former astronaut, spoke quietly but was self-assured as she testified at a pretrial hearing involving charges that she had tried to kidnap Captain Shipman, a romantic rival, who is in the Air Force, after a marathon drive from Texas to Florida.

results.abstract: Serena Williams defeats Angelique Kerber in first round of US Open; photos (M)

headline.main: After Trailblazer Is Honored, Williamses Carry On Her Legacy

results.snippet: The entire match in which Venus Williams pummeled Kira Nagy took only 54 minutes, several minutes shorter than a ceremony that honored Althea Gibson.

multimedia.caption: First Day at the Open
multimedia.credit: Beautiful weather and record crowds graced the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center for the first day of competition.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Beautiful weather and record crowds graced the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center for the first day of competition.

results.lead_paragraph: On her way to the court on opening night at the United States Open, Venus Williams seemed momentarily flummoxed. In the hallway from the locker room at Arthur Ashe Stadium, she was greeted yesterday by an array of stars, an eye-popping lineup of African-American women who came to honor the tennis icon Althea Gibson. Williams paused to kiss Jackie Joyner-Kersee, to say hello to Roberta Flack, seeming as if she wanted to hug each of them. For a rare moment near a tennis court, Williams looked positively overwhelmed.

results.abstract: Capt Lisa M Nowak, Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted romantic rival in Orlando, Fla, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges (M)

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut to Enter a Plea Of Insanity on Assault Charges

results.snippet: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando, Fla., airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges.
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando, Fla., airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges, according to a notice filed yesterday in State Circuit Court in Orlando. The filing notes that Captain Nowak has lost 15 percent of her body mass because of manic-depressive disorder. It also cites problems in her marriage and an inability to confide in friends or family members.

results.abstract: NASA safety chief Bryan D O'Connor says internal investigation has found no evidence of drunkenness among astronauts before space missions and states safeguards are in place to prevent it; review is follow-up to July report by independent health experts citing two unverified accounts of problem drinking before flights (M)

headline.main: A Follow-Up Investigation by NASA Finds No Evidence of Drunken Astronauts

results.snippet: An internal investigation has found no evidence of heavy drinking or drunkenness among astronauts before space missions, NASA officials said.
results.lead_paragraph: An internal investigation has found no evidence of heavy drinking or drunkenness among astronauts before space missions, NASA officials said Wednesday. In a report summarizing the investigation, NASA's safety chief, the former astronaut Bryan D. O'Connor, said that although stories had circulated about astronauts abusing alcohol before missions, nothing was found to support them.

results.abstract: Capt. Lisa Nowak has one less problem before her case.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Freed of Ankle Monitor

results.snippet: Capt. Lisa Nowak has one less problem before her case.
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Lisa Nowak's complaints about an ankle monitor, a condition of her release from jail for confronting a fellow officer and romantic rival for another astronaut, were legion.

results.abstract: Judge Marc L Lubet rules that Capt Lisa M Nowak, former astronaut, can remove electronic monitoring bracelet while she awaits trial on charges of attacking romantic rival Capt Colleen Shipman; Nowak is not allowed to contact Shipman or Cmdr William A Oefelein, former shuttle pilot both women dated; photo (S)

headline.main: National Briefing: South: Florida: Ex-Astronaut May Remove Ankle Monitor

results.snippet: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, left, a Navy officer and former astronaut, can remove an electronic monitoring bracelet from her ankle while she awaits trial on charges of attacking a romantic rival, a judge ruled. Captain Nowak had said in court that the...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, left, a Navy officer and former astronaut, can remove an electronic monitoring bracelet from her ankle while she awaits trial on charges of attacking a romantic rival, a judge ruled. Captain Nowak had said in court that the bracelet was expensive, bulky and uncomfortable. The judge, Marc L. Lubet of Orange County Circuit Court, said that those claims did not matter, but that Captain Nowak had behaved well enough to remove the device. She is prohibited from contacting the former rival, Capt. Colleen Shipman of the Air Force, or Cmdr. William A. Oefelein of the Navy, the former shuttle pilot both women dated, Judge Lubet said. Captain Nowak, 44, was arrested in February after confronting Captain Shipman at the Orlando airport.
